data.desc: return a handy array of meta-data for this subset. Default subset is sentences, but it can be anything.
data.example:
nlp('The stage was set for the Alan Parsons Project! Which I believe was some sort of hovercraft.').data()
//[{normal:'the stage was set...'}]

found.desc: is the match empty or not

all.desc: zooms-out from a subset back to the whole input

debug.desc: pretty-print the current selection to the console
debug.example: nlp('wayne‚Äôs world, party time, excellent- weeeyooweeeyoo!').out()

out.desc: render parsed data as an output. supports `text`, `normal`, `array`, `html`, `grid`, `color`, `debug`, `csv`
out.example: nlp('you might say there‚Äôs a little Uter in all of us').match('#Adjective uter').out('html') //little Uter

whitespace.desc: set before or after whitespace on each match
whitespace.example:
nlp('We like Roy! We like Roy!').whitespace.before('   ').out()
//We like Roy!   We like Roy!

normalize.desc: transforms whitespace, case, punctuation, contractions and values, so that they are more standard and workable
normalize.example:
nlp(' so... you like   DONUTS? have all the donuts in the WORLD!!!').normalize().sentences(0).out()
//So you like donuts?

length.desc: how many individual matches in the result

random.desc: sample a random section of n matches

sort.desc: set a new ordering for the sentences/results. Accepts `alphabetical`, `chronological`, `length`, `wordcount`, `frequency`

forEach.desc: do something on each result independently

map.desc: create a new array from these results

filter.desc: select only the results that return true for some function

find.desc: select only the first result that returns true

reduce.desc: combine the results of a function into one thing

toTitleCase.desc: set the first letter of each term as a capital
toTitleCase.example:
nlp('jupiter, pluto and mars').nouns().toTitleCase().all().out()
//Jupiter, Pluto and Mars.

toUpperCase.desc: set all the letters as a capital
toUpperCase.example:
nlp('Dental plan. Lisa needs braces.').match('dental .').toUpperCase().out()
//DENTAL PLAN.

toLowerCase.desc: set all the letters as a not-capital. Even acronyms and first-letters of sentences

toCamelCase.desc: remove whitespace and titlecase the words

hyphenate.desc: remove whitespace and add a hyphenate between the words

dehyphenate.desc: remove hyphens and add normal whitespace between words

trim.desc: remove leading and trailing whitespace from each match

getPunctuation.desc: get an array of trailing-punctuation for the results

setPunctuation.example:
nlp('there\'s a new mexico?').sentences().setPunctuation('!??').out()
//there's a new mexico!??

insertBefore.desc: append a word (or words) before each match

insertAfter.desc: append a word (or words) after each match
insertAfter.example:
nlp('i know so many words').insertAfter('bigly').all().out()
//i know so many words bigly

insertAt.desc: insert a word or words at a known index (zero-based)
insertAt.example:
nlp('so you are from Africa?').insertAt(2, 'like,').all().out()
//so you are like, from africa?

lump.desc: merge matches into one term, with shared tags.

replaceWith.desc: turn the current selection into something else. Essentially just delete() -> insertAt(). The second param says whether to keep original tags around.
replaceWith.example:
nlp('it was the worst of times').match('worst').replaceWith('blurst', true).all().out()
//it was the blurst of times

replace.desc: turn a new selection into something else. Essentially just match() -> delete() -> insertAt(). Third optional param keeps original tags around.
replace.example:
nlp('trust me folks, big league.').replace('big league','bigly').all().out()
//trust me folks, bigly.

delete.desc: remove a match from the Text permanently. For a temporary filter, see `.not()`
delete.example:
nlp('you don‚Äôt win friends with salad').delete('do not').out()
//you win friends with salad

slice.desc: grab a subset of the results
slice.example:
nlp('Homer, have you been eating that sandwich again?').terms().slice(0, 3).out()
//Homer, have you

clone.desc: copy the object, so changes no longer effect the original (make it ~immutable)
clone.example:
nlp('would somebody please think of the children').clone().toUpperCase().parent.out()
//would somebody please think of the children

concat.example:
nlp('My name is Otto').concat('and i love to get blotto').sentences().length
//1

flatten.desc: turn a list of results into one result
flatten.example:
nlp('sex cauldron? I thought they closed that place down.').flatten().length
//1

match.desc:
zoom-in to a subset of the text, using a [regex-like syntax](https:
//github.com/nlp-compromise/compromise/wiki/Match-syntax)
match.example:
nlp('we understand, we are from the land of chocolate.').match('land of #Noun').out()
//land of chocolate

not.desc: return parts of the text that do not match. Like .match() but opposite.

if.desc: returns only the sets which contain this match. Like a Array.filter() method, for your results
if.example:
nlp('We‚Äôre here, we‚Äôre clear, we don‚Äôt want anymore bears.').clauses().if('anymore').out()
//we don't want anymore bears

ifNo.desc: removes any sets that have this match
ifNo.example:
nlp('We‚Äôre here, we‚Äôre clear, we don‚Äôt want anymore bears.').clauses().ifNo('anymore').out()
//We're here, we're clear,

has.desc: quick check to see if this match is found
has.example:
nlp('I am the very model of a modern Major-General').has('#Pronoun')
//true,

before.desc: find a match, and return everything infront of it
before.example:
nlp('one two three four five').before('three').out()
//one two

after.desc: find a match, and return everything following of it
after.example:
nlp('one two three four five').after('three').out()
//four five

tag.desc: set a particular interpretation for these terms. Can tag your match as anything. Supported tags do dependency/conflict logic.
tag.example:
nlp('Michael Apple ate a delicious apple.').match('#FirstName apple').tag('Person').people().out()
//Michael Apple

unTag.desc: remove a particular tag for all these terms. Passing in a '*' removes all the current tags.
unTag.example:
nlp('they made a catch & scored a run').match(['run','catch']).unTag('#Verb').nouns().out('array')
//catch, run

canBe.desc: return only terms that have no conflicts with this tag

data.desc: return a handy array of meta-data for this the contractions in this text
data.example:
nlp(' I‚Äôd like to request seventeen dollars for a push broom rebristling').contractions().data()
//[{text:'I'd'}]

expand.example:
nlp('He‚Äôs the greatest guy in history').contractions().expand().out('')
//He is

contract.desc: turn did not into didn't, etc.
contract.example:
nlp('He is about to hit a chestnut tree').contractions().contract().out('')
//He's

contracted.desc: show only the contractions that are currently contracted -eg. `i'll` but not `i will`
contracted.example:
nlp('Lisa, I‚Äôd like to buy your rock.').contractions().contracted().out('')
//I'd

expanded.desc: show only the contractions that are currently not contracted -eg. `he would` but not `he'd`
expanded.example:
nlp('Lisa, I would like to buy your rock.').contractions().expanded().out('')
//I would

data.desc: return an array of meta-data about the dates and times in this text
data.example:
nlp('Finally, I just stopped caring. Luckily for me, it was 1980 and no one noticed.').dates().data()
//[{text:'1980'}]

toShortForm.example:
nlp('April, June, and Sept').dates().toShortForm().all().out()
//Apr, Jun, and Sept

toLongForm.example:
nlp('April, June, and Sept').dates().toShortForm().all().out()
//April, June, and September

data.desc: return a handy array of meta-data for the n-grams in this text. accepts an obj with `max` or `size` number
data.example:
nlp('love love me do.').ngrams({max:3}).data()
//[{text:'love', count:2, size:1}..]

unigrams.desc: return only the ngrams of size 1
unigrams.example:
nlp('University of Toronto, in toronto').ngrams().unigrams(0).data()
//[{normal:'toronto', count:2, size:1}]

bigrams.desc: return only the ngrams of size 2
bigrams.example:
nlp('The University of Ryerson and University of Toronto, in toronto').ngrams().bigrams(0).data()
//[{normal:'university of', count:2, size:2}]

trigrams.desc: return only the ngrams of size 3
trigrams.example:
nlp('we like Roy! we like Roy!').ngrams().trigrams(0).data()
//[{normal:'we like roy', count:2, size:3}]

sort.desc: the default sort for ngrams - count, then size, then character length. (called by default)
sort.example:
nlp('i scream, you scream, we all scream for icecream.').ngrams().sort().first().out()
//scream

data.desc: return a handy array of meta-data for the nouns in this text
data.example:
nlp('Lunchlady Doris, have you got any grease?').nouns().data()
//[{text:'Lunchlady Doris'}, {text:'grease'}]

isPlural.example:
nlp('All my life I‚Äôve had one dream, to accomplish my many goals.').nouns().isPlural().out()
//goals

hasPlural.desc: return only the nouns which can be plural (sometimes called 'countable' nouns)
hasPlural.example:
nlp('bring joy to the air, water, earth, and sky.').nouns().hasPlural().length
//0

toPlural.desc: transform singular nouns into their plural (inflected) forms

toSingular.desc: transform plural nouns into their singular forms

toPossessive.desc: transform nouns into a possessive form  - John ‚Üí John's

data.desc: return a handy array of meta-data for the sentences in this text
data.example:
nlp('hi everybody! Hi Dr. Nick!').sentences().data().length
//[{normal:'hi everybody'}, {normal:'hi dr nick'}]

prepend.desc: add a word (or words) at the beginning of these sentences, and move the sentnece's titlecase appropriately
prepend.example:
nlp('I know so many words.').sentences().prepend('believe me').out()
//Believe me, I know so many words.

append.desc: add a word (or words) at the end of these sentences, and move the sentnece's punctuation appropriately
append.example:
nlp('I know so many words.').sentences().append('big league').out()
//I know so many words big league.

toPastTense.desc: transform the sentences so that they are in the past tense
toPastTense.example:
nlp('I pay the Homer tax.').sentences().toPastTense().out()
//I paid the Homer tax.

toPresentTense.desc: transform the sentences so that they are in the present tense
toPresentTense.example:
nlp('I paid the Homer tax.').sentences().toPresentTense().out()
//I pay the Homer tax.

toFutureTense.desc: transform the sentences so that they are in the future tense
toFutureTense.example:
nlp('That‚Äôs the home-owner tax.').sentences().toFutureTense().out()
//That will be the home-owner tax

toContinuous.desc: like present tense, but still happening. ('walks'->'is walking')

toNegative.desc: turn the sentence negative, so that it means the opposite thing
toNegative.example:
nlp('Now make like my pants, and split.').sentences(0).toNegative().out()
//Now do not make like my pants, and split.

toPositive.desc: if the sentence is negatively-stated, make it say the opposite thing
toPositive.example:
nlp('The goggles do nothing!').sentences().toPositive().out()
//The goggles do everything!

isPassive.desc: return only sentences that are passive-tense
isPassive.example:
nlp('you were saved by the bell').sentences().isPassive().out()
//you were saved by the bell

isQuestion.desc: return only sentences that are questions
isQuestion.example:
nlp('Dogs are funny. Are they funny? Yes they are.').sentences().isQuestion().out('array')
//['are they funny']

toExclamation.desc: replace the sentence's end punctuation with an exclamation point
toExclamation.example:
nlp('sweet balls of fire?').sentences().toExclamation().out()
//sweet balls of fire!

toQuestion.desc: turn the sentence into a question
toQuestion.example:
nlp('Stupider like a fox.').sentences().toQuestion().out()
//Stupider like a fox?

toStatement.desc: turn the sentence into a statement. Replace it's end punctuation with a period
toStatement.example:
nlp('Go out on a Tuesday? Who am I, Charlie Sheen?').sentences(0).toStatement().out()
//Go out on a Tuesday. Who am I, Charlie Sheen?

data.desc: return a handy array of meta-data of people mentioned in the text
data.example:
nlp('The bone-rattling bass of Mel Schacher? The competent drum work of Don Brewer?').people().data()
//[{text:' Mel Schacher'}, {text:'Don Brewer'}]

pronoun.desc: find the pronoun used to refer to the person, or suggest one based on their inferred gender.

data.desc: return a handy array of meta-data for the numbers and values in this text
data.example:
nlp('I‚Äôd like to request seventeen dollars for a push broom rebristling').values().data()
//[{number:17, TextValue:{ Ordinal:'seventeenth'}, NumericValue:{ Ordinal:'17th'}} ]

noDates.desc: remove numbers that are also dates, like in 'June 5th 1999'.
noDates.example:
nlp('in 2016, I‚Äôm going to party like it‚Äôs on sale for $19.99.').values().noDates().length
//1

toNumber.desc: turn a written number like `five thousand five hundred` into it's numerical form, like `5500`
toNumber.example:
nlp('ten things i hate about you').values().toNumber().all().out()
//10 things i hate about you

toText.desc: turn a number like `5,500` into it's textual form, like `five thousand five hundred`
toText.example:
nlp('10 things i hate about you').values().toText().all().out()
//ten things i hate about you

toNice.desc: turn a number into numerical form, but with nice commas, like `5,500`
toNice.example:
nlp('five hundred sixty two thousand, four hundred and seven').values().toNice().all().out()
//'562,407'

numbers.desc: return the actual javascript integers (or floats)

greaterThan.desc: return only the values larger than a given value

lessThan.desc: return only the values smaller than a given value

between.desc: return values between a max and min - wrapper of .greaterThan(min).lessThan(max)

isEqual.desc: return only the values equal to a given value

add.desc: increment the current number by a given integer

subtract.desc: subtract the current number by a given integer

increment.desc: add one to the current number

decrement.desc: subtract one from the current number

data.desc: return a handy array of meta-data for the verbs and their auxillaries in this text
data.example:
nlp('he will have been walking quickly').verbs().data()
//[{verb:'walking', auxillary:'will have been', adverb:'quickly'}]

conjugation.desc: which form of is the verb in currently? PastTense, PresentTense, Infinitive, etc
conjugation.example:
nlp('My cat‚Äôs breath smells like cat food').verbs().conjugation()
//['PresentTense']

conjugate.desc: blast-out all conjugated forms of these verbs

isSingular.desc: return only the verbs that are singular, like 'is' but not 'are'
isSingular.example:
nlp('we were discussing Wittgenstein over a game of backgammon').verbs().isSingular().out('array')
//[{text:'were discussing'}]

isPlural.desc: return only the verbs that are plural, like 'are' but not 'is'
isPlural.example:
nlp('We were sitting in Barney‚Äôs car').verbs().isPlural().out('array')
//[]

isPositive.desc: return only the verbs that are not negative, like 'would sing' but not 'would not sing'
isPositive.example:
nlp('Dear Miss Hoover, you have Lyme disease.').verbs().isPositive().length
    //1

isNegative.desc: return only the verbs that are negative, like 'would not sing' but not 'would sing'
isNegative.example:
nlp('Dear Miss Hoover, you have Lyme disease.').verbs().isNegative().length
//0

toNegative.desc: make the verbs mean the opposite thing - `walk`->`did not walk` etc
toNegative.example:
nlp('Dear Miss Hoover, you have Lyme disease.').verbs().toNegative().out()
//do not have

toPositive.desc: if the verb is negative, make it not negative
toPositive.example:
nlp('Dear Miss Hoover, you do not have Lyme disease').verbs().toPositive().out()
//have

toPastTense.desc: turn the verb into past tense - `walk`->`walked` etc.

toPresentTense.desc: turn the verb into present tense - `walked`->`walks` etc.
toPresentTense.example:
nlp('you ate the sandwich?').verbs().toPresentTense().out()
//you eat the sandwich?

toFutureTense.desc: turn the verb into future tense - `walked`->`will walk` etc.

toGerund.desc: turn the verb into 'continual' tense - `walked`->`walking` etc.

asAdjective.desc: conjugate the verb to its adjectival form - `walk`->`walkable`

stripPeriods.example:
nlp('Director of the F.B.I.').acronyms().stripPeriods().out()
//Director of the FBI

addPeriods.example:
nlp('Director of the FBI').acronyms().addPeriods().out()
//Director of the F.B.I.

data.desc: return an array of meta-data for the acronyms in this text
data.example:
nlp('In the USA, the big CIA. The Bloods and the Crips, and the KKK.').acronyms().data()
//[{text:'USA'...}]

data.desc: return an array of meta-data for the adjectives and their adverbs
data.example:
nlp('Guys, we have to assume our guns are useless. Throw them in the lake.').adjectives().data()
//[{text:'useless'}]

data.desc: return an array of meta-data for the adverbs in this text
data.example:
nlp('truly, madly, deeply').adverbs().data()
//[{text:'truly'...}]

data.desc: return an array of words split by sentence phrase (clause)
data.example:
nlp('All right, Colossus, you‚Äôre free to go, but stay away from Death Mountain').clauses().data()
//[{normal:'all right'}, {normal:'Colossus'}, {normal:'you're free to go'},]

data.desc: return an array of parsed hashtags used in the text
data.example:
nlp('oh, but where is the #anykey').hashTags().data()
//[{normal:'anykey'}]

data.desc: return an array of subsequences beginning at the start of each sentence or match
data.example:
nlp('Who controls the British crown? Who keeps the metric system down?').startGrams().data()
//[{normal:'who', size:1, count:2}...]

data.desc: return an array of subsequences ending at the end of each sentence or match
data.example:
nlp('you think that‚Äôs a knife? I‚Äôll show you a knife.').endGrams().data()
//[{normal:'knife', count:2, size:1}...]

data.desc: return an array of named-organizations in this text
data.example:
nlp('Your dreams may vary from those of Globex Corporation, its subsidiaries and shareholders.').organizations().data()
//[{text:'Globex Corporation'}]

data.desc: return an array of parsed phonenumbers in this text
data.example:
nlp('Moe Sizlak. That‚Äôs right. I‚Äôm a surgeon. (800) 555-0000.').phoneNumbers().data()
//[{text:'(800) 555-0000'}]

data.desc: return an array of locations mentioned in this text
data.example:
nlp('you could still go to McGill, the Harvard of Canada!').places().data()
//[{normal:'canada'}]

data.desc: return a list of phrases between ( ) brackets.
data.example:
nlp('Use a pointed stick (a pencil) or a similar tool').parentheses().data()
//[{text:'a pencil'}..]

data.desc: return an array of question sentences in this text
data.example:
nlp('are you saying boo, or boo-urns?').questions().data().length
//1

data.desc: return an array of meta-data with the parsed quoations
data.example:
nlp('the he said "crazy like a fox!".').quotations().data().length
//1

data.desc: return an array of sentences that are not questions
data.example:
nlp('i was saying boo-urns.').statements().data()
//[{normal:'i was saying boo-urns'}]

data.desc: split all words into individual results, and return their metadata
data.example:
nlp('we should all be more like little Ruttiger').terms().data()
//[{text:'we'}, {text:'should'}...]

strip.desc: grab all the things that are possessive, like "Homer Simpson's"

data.desc: return the people, places, and organizations of this text
data.example:
nlp('Hey everybody, I‚Äôm lookin‚Äô for Amanda Hugginkiss').topics().data()
//[{text:'Amanda Hugginkiss'}]

data.desc: return an array of urls mentioned in this text
data.example:
nlp('üëè http://simpsons.wikia.com').urls().data()
//[{text:'http://simpsons.wikia.com'}]
